00004 #ifdef DUTCH
00005 
00006 
00007 
00008 /*
00009 
00010 ******************************************************************************************************
00011 **                                  IMPORTANT TRANSLATION NOTES                                     **
00012 ******************************************************************************************************
00013 
00014 GENERAL INSTRUCTIONS
00015 - Always be aware that foreign strings should be of equal or shorter length than the English equivalent.  
00016       I know that this is difficult to do on many occasions due to the nature of foreign languages when 
00017       compared to English.  By doing so, this will greatly reduce the amount of work on both sides.  In 
00018       most cases (but not all), JA2 interfaces were designed with just enough space to fit the English word.  
00019       The general rule is if the string is very short (less than 10 characters), then it's short because of 
00020       interface limitations.  On the other hand, full sentences commonly have little limitations for length.  
00021       Strings in between are a little dicey.
00022 - Never translate a string to appear on multiple lines.  All strings L"This is a really long string...", 
00023       must fit on a single line no matter how long the string is.  All strings start with L" and end with ",
00024 - Never remove any extra spaces in strings.  In addition, all strings containing multiple sentences only 
00025       have one space after a period, which is different than standard typing convention.  Never modify sections 
00026       of strings contain combinations of % characters.  These are special format characters and are always 
00027       used in conjunction with other characters.  For example, %s means string, and is commonly used for names,
00028       locations, items, etc.  %d is used for numbers.  %c%d is a character and a number (such as A9).  
00029       %% is how a single % character is built.  There are countless types, but strings containing these 
00030       special characters are usually commented to explain what they mean.  If it isn't commented, then 
00031       if you can't figure out the context, then feel free to ask SirTech.
00032 - Comments are always started with // Anything following these two characters on the same line are 
00033       considered to be comments.  Do not translate comments.  Comments are always applied to the following 
00034       string(s) on the next line(s), unless the comment is on the same line as a string.  
00035 - All new comments made by SirTech will use "//@@@ comment" (without the quotes) notation.  By searching 
00036       for @@@ everytime you recieve a new version, it will simplify your task and identify special instructions.
00037   Commonly, these types of comments will be used to ask you to abbreviate a string.  Please leave the 
00038       comments intact, and SirTech will remove them once the translation for that particular area is resolved.
00039 - If you have a problem or question with translating certain strings, please use "//!!! comment" 
00040       (without the quotes).  The syntax is important, and should be identical to the comments used with @@@ 
00041       symbols.  SirTech will search for !!! to look for your problems and questions.  This is a more 
00042       efficient method than detailing questions in email, so try to do this whenever possible.
00043 
00044 
00045       
00046 FAST HELP TEXT -- Explains how the syntax of fast help text works.
00047 **************
00048 
00049 1) BOLDED LETTERS
00050       The popup help text system supports special characters to specify the hot key(s) for a button.  
00051       Anytime you see a '|' symbol within the help text string, that means the following key is assigned
00052       to activate the action which is usually a button.  
00053 
00054       EX:  L"|Map Screen" 
00055 
00056       This means the 'M' is the hotkey.  In the game, when somebody hits the 'M' key, it activates that
00057       button.  When translating the text to another language, it is best to attempt to choose a word that
00058       uses 'M'.  If you can't always find a match, then the best thing to do is append the 'M' at the end
00059       of the string in this format:
00060 
00061       EX:  L"Ecran De Carte (|M)"  (this is the French translation)
00062 
00063       Other examples are used multiple times, like the Esc key  or "|E|s|c" or Space -> (|S|p|a|c|e)
00064 
00065 2) NEWLINE
00066   Any place you see a \n within the string, you are looking at another string that is part of the fast help
00067       text system.  \n notation doesn't need to be precisely placed within that string, but whereever you wish 
00068       to start a new line. 
00069 
00070       EX:  L"Clears all the mercs' positions,\nand allows you to re-enter them manually." 
00071 
00072       Would appear as:
00073 
00074                         Clears all the mercs' positions,
00075                         and allows you to re-enter them manually.
00076 
00077       NOTE:  It is important that you don't pad the characters adjacent to the \n with spaces.  If we did this
00078              in the above example, we would see
00079 
00080       WRONG WAY -- spaces before and after the \n
00081       EX:  L"Clears all the mercs' positions, \n and allows you to re-enter them manually." 
00082 
00083       Would appear as: (the second line is moved in a character)
00084             
00085                         Clears all the mercs' positions,
00086                          and allows you to re-enter them manually.
00087 
00088 
00089 @@@ NOTATION
00090 ************
00091 
00092       Throughout the text files, you'll find an assortment of comments.  Comments are used to describe the
00093       text to make translation easier, but comments don't need to be translated.  A good thing is to search for
00094       "@@@" after receiving new version of the text file, and address the special notes in this manner.  
00095 
00096 !!! NOTATION
00097 ************
00098 
00099       As described above, the "!!!" notation should be used by you to ask questions and address problems as
00100       SirTech uses the "@@@" notation.
00101 
00102 */
00103
